properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: 10 to 25 cm of snow is expected this weekend. Hazards: 10 to 25 cm of snow Poor road conditions due to accumulating snow Timing: Snow will begin Friday overnight and last into Sunday. The heaviest snow is expected Saturday afternoon through Sunday morning. Discussion: An approaching system will spread snow across the Bruce Peninsula and along the French River to the Quebec border. Drifting and local blowing snow will be possible in exposed areas. The snow should lighten up Sunday morning, but may not completely taper off until Sunday evening. A Snowfall Warning will be considered as this event draws nearer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-11T13:00:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-10T21:01:40-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2363668881.2020
Area: West Nipissing - French River, North Bay - Powassan - Mattawa
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Advisory Alert Update - Civil Emergency
properties.Summary:
Description: This emergency advisory alert is being issued for the province of Saskatchewan. All travelers returning from outside of Canada are subject to a mandatory 14 day self isolation order. Violation of the order may result in a fine of 2000 dollars.
Expires: 2020-12-23T23:45:00-06:00

Area: Province of Saskatchewan
properties.Author: SK Provincial Emergency Communications Centre

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A slow moving low pressure system over northern Hudson Bay combined with a building Arctic ridge of high pressure over western Nunavut will produce strong winds over the Kivalliq and Melville Peninsula over the next several days. By Thursday afternoon, temperatures falling into the minus twenties combined with wind gusts up to 80 km/h will create ideal conditions for heavy blowing snow. Blizzard or near blizzard conditions are likely with significantly reduced visibilities. Over the Kivalliq, conditions will deteriorate Thursday morning with improvement forecast by Friday morning. Over the Melville Peninsula, conditions will begin to deteriorate Thursday afternoon and improve Friday overnight. Please stay alert for updated bulletins as this winter storm watch may be upgraded to a blizzard warning for some communities as the event nears. And please refer to your local forecast for additional information on wind speeds and timing. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-11T01:06:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-10T09:07:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3695874244.2020
Area: Baker Lake, Rankin Region including Whale Cove, Chesterfield Inlet
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: 5 to 15 cm of snow and ice pellets, plus a risk of freezing rain, is expected this weekend. Hazards: 5 to 15 cm of snow and ice pellets; up to 20 cm may be possible for places like Parry Sound and Huntsville Poor road conditions due to accumulating snow and possible freezing rain Timing: Snow will begin Friday overnight and last into Sunday. Discussion: An approaching system will spread precipitation across Georgian Bay and east to the Ottawa River beginning Friday overnight. The track of this low will determine how the precipitation falls, whether it be as snow, ice pellets, or possibly even freezing rain, but right now a general range of 5 to 15 cm of snow and ice pellets seems reasonable with a risk of freezing rain. A slight shift south in the track could mean up to 20 cm of snow is possible in places like Huntsville and Parry Sound. Environment Canada meteorologists will continue to monitor this developing situation. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-11T12:59:48-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-10T21:00:48-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1261817583.2020
Area: Midland - Coldwater - Orr Lake, Huntsville - Baysville, Town of Parry Sound - Rosseau - Killbear Park, Port Carling - Port Severn, Bracebridge - Gravenhurst, Oxtongue Lake - Fort Irwin - Northern Haliburton County, Haliburton - Minden - Southern Haliburton County, Bancroft - Hastings Highlands - Denbigh, Petawawa - Pembroke - Cobden, Barry's Bay - Killaloe, Renfrew - Arnprior - Calabogie, Owen Sound - Blue Mountains - Northern Grey County, Hanover - Dundalk - Southern Grey County

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow today with a risk of freezing rain this morning. A fast moving weather system will bring an area of snow to northwestern Ontario beginning early this morning and tapering off this afternoon. Snowfall amounts around 5 cm are possible. There will also be a threat of freezing rain this morning. Motorists and pedestrians are advised to exercise caution as roadways and surfaces may become icy and slippery. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-10T21:58:45-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-10T05:59:45-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0841834980.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, ice pellets, and a prolonged period of freezing rain is possible this weekend. Hazards: Freezing rain, possibly lasting several hours 3-8 mm of ice accretion Local power outages and slippery surfaces Timing: Precipitation will begin Saturday morning and last into Sunday. Discussion: An approaching system will bring a transition zone of precipitation with it from roughly the Dundalk Highlands east to Ottawa and eastern Ontario. Along this zone, several hours of freezing rain may be possible, favouring ice build up on untreated surfaces and power lines. Precipitation will likely include a mix of rain, snow, ice pellets, and freezing rain. Snowfall accumulations are generally anticipated to be limited to 5 cm or less. A Freezing Rain Warning will be considered as this event draws nearer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-11T12:58:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-10T20:59:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0741950892.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Mixed bag of precipitation for the weekend. A developing low over Texas will affect Southern Quebec beginning Saturday morning. This system will intensify as it approaches the province. A mixed bag of precipitation will accompany this system. Generally, regions to the north and east will see significant snowfall amounts. An area of freezing rain could also affect part of the province from Saturday evening to Sunday morning, especially regions just north of Montreal and areas along the St. Lawrence River toward Quebec City. Poor driving conditions are expected. Consider modifying any non-essential travel plans. For the moment, the low pressure system's track remains fairly uncertain. The exact types and amounts of expected precipitation will depend on this track. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-11T12:24:06-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-10T20:25:06-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1935697793.2020

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. A low pressure system near Southampton Island will lead to very strong winds gusting up to 80 km/h over Naujaat and Coral Harbour today and overnight. This will lead to significantly reduced visibilities in heavy blowing snow. In Naujaat, blizzard conditions developed this morning and will continue through to Friday morning. At Coral Harbour, the blizzard will begin later this afternoon and persist into Friday afternoon before easing. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-11T12:26:25-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-10T20:27:25-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2074764500.2020
Area: Naujaat, Coral Harbour
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A slow moving low pressure system over northern Hudson Bay combined with a building Arctic ridge of high pressure over western Nunavut will produce strong winds over the Kivalliq and Melville Peninsula over the next few days. Northwesterly winds will strengthen this afternoon in Sanirajak and Igloolik, these winds combined with falling snow will lead to reduced visibilities in blowing snow. Conditions will gradually improve through the day on Friday. Please stay alert for updated bulletins as this winter storm watch may be upgraded to a blizzard warning for some communities as the event nears. And please refer to your local forecast for additional information on wind speeds and timing. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-11T07:10:14-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-10T15:11:14-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2706565967.2020
Area: Sanirajak, Igloolik
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A sloppy Friday morning commute is expected. Total snowfall: up to 15 cm in the east, with lesser amounts in the west. Locations: Avalon Peninsula. Time span: early Friday morning until early Friday evening. Maximum wind gusts: northerly 60 to 70 km/h. Remarks: A low pressure system is expected to pass southeast of the island on Friday. Snow will begin overnight and potentially mix with rain along parts of the coast later in the day. Temperatures are forecast to remain slightly above the freezing mark throughout the event. As a result, driving conditions are expected to be hazardous, especially during the morning commute, as the settling snow will become slushy on the roads and walkways. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-11T11:07:39-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-10T19:08:39-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1687580183.2020
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility is expected tonight into early Friday morning. Hazards: Near zero visibility in fog, particularly in areas of higher terrain Untreated surfaces may develop black ice, creating slippery conditions Timing: Widespread dense fog is expected to develop tonight and will dissipate by 11 AM Friday ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
